Interesting that no one knows the derivation! Chinese Proverb? Maimonides? Lao-Tzu? Anne Isabella Thackeray Ritchie? Italian Adage? Native American Saying? Mao Zedong? Often thought to be from the Bible but no one knows.

@realmoney May 03, 2019 | 01:49 PM EDT DOUG KASS A Reality Check Today's optimism is a bit hard to fathom especially after the worst ISM services print in almost two years and a weak manufacturing number.
Meanwhile bond yields are slightly lower (-2 basis points) on the day - and not for a nanosecond responding to the better jobs number. @jimcramer @tomkeene

@realmoney For those that are keeping count, $AMZN shares traded between $1500-$1780 during the first quarter of 2019. Berkshire's 13F filing will reflect the purchases in that period as the company did not own stock in Amazon at year end 2018. @jimcramer @SquawkCNBC @beckyquick
A Reality Check on @realmoney realmoney.thestreet.com/doug…
Nearly everyone is consensus and for the same two (sic) often repeated reasons: the Fed and stocks are rising. Its never so easy... @realmoney

@terranovajoe @ScottWapnerCNBC @cnbcfastmoney Todd and Ted have $13 billion each. One of them, or both started buying $AAPL and then Warren joined them and sized it up. It didnt sound in Becky's interview that Warren was considering sizing up $AMZN (which is my largest long)

@terranovajoe @cnbcfastmoney @ScottWapnerCNBC Joe, your position on needing to utilize the large cash position at Berkshire might be correct if Warren purchased it, but he did not It is part of one of the two $13 billion tranches that Todd and Ted manage not what Warren manages!
Thx my largest long
@AAPL sales since 2015 are +5% and operating profits are -8%. $AAPL, a large holding at Berkshire, is not a growth stock. It is a value stock.

In no way is Warren Buffett deviating from his value approach in his purchase of $AMZN. Buffett/Berkshire is not making a statement, at all. A relatively small position in $AMZN in his portfolio doesnt move the needle for Berkshire. @cnbcfastmoney @jimcramer @tomkeene
Buffett specifically said the buy of Amazon was not his.

The fact that $AMZN is +$60/share today on a purchase by Berkshire Hathaway of at least five weeks ago (it probably was put on 2-3 months ago) is testimony to an increasingly speculative and complacent market. I could call it something else (silly comes to mind),
but I am trying to be politic at the end of the week! @jimcramer @tomkeene @cnbcfastmoney @carlquintanilla @beckyquick @SquawkCNBC @TeamCavuto @LizClaman
$AMZN +$60 @realmoney

Let me get this straight, Goldman Sachs, in December, expected four rate increases in 2019. Since then Real GDP rose much more than anticipated and now they expect no hikes. Ok. @saraeisen @carlquintanilla
Berkshire buys $AMZN two to three months ago and everything rallies. “Forgiving” is a description I used this week regarding the market - I am trying to be diplomatic. @tomkeene @jimcramer
agree m
On @realmoney Why I continue to short bonds (I started yesterday) realmoney.thestreet.com/doug… @tomkeene @jimcramer @SquawkCNBC

I have to respectfully disagree. In part because of his age, huge float generation, cash buildup and growing size of enterprise - Warren has delegated a large amt of investment responsibility to Todd and Ted. This is not new. With that comes differing invt styles and views...

The DNA changes (and has been changing) for years as Berkshire becomes an ever larger conglomerate. It results in diminishing returns (of ROI, sales/profit growth) - as size matters. This is a point I made when I presented at Berkshire's Annual Meeting five years ago.
@jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney Today Berkshire is more of an image of the S&P Index than at any time in its history. That is the outgrowth of his success.

Guest on @business with @tomkeene is making the same comparison many are making about stocks v bonds (equities are cheap to expensive fixed income). But he is saying high yield is cheap v stocks (because HY is less volatile). In other words someone else comparing
an asset that is perceived to be inexpensive only when judged against an expensive asset class. Makes zero sense to me! @tomkeene @pimmfox HY over Treasuries is very very narrow.

@realmoney May 03, 2019 | 07:39 AM EDT DOUG KASS Berkshire Finally Embraces Amazon "You do not want to give Jeff Bezos a seven-year head start." - Warren Buffett. Berkshire Hathaway (May, 2017) Though the purchase was from one of The Oracle of Omaha's kids (either Todd Combs

or Ted Weschler), Warren Buffett's imprimatur was bestowed on Amazon last night when it was revealed that Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) has purchased shares in Amazon (AMZN) . (It is unclear of the size of the investment or when and at what price the stock was purchased by

Berkshire). I purchased and placed Amazon on my Best Idea List on December 26, 2018 at $1383. It is my largest holding and, as I have previously noted, my favorite large cap stock for 2019. The shares are trading +$48 to over $1945 in pre-market trading this morning.
Here is my investment thesis and an explanation of my aggressive price target for Amazon. realmoney.thestreet.com/doug… @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @CNBCFastMoney @BeckyQuick @andrewrsorkin

@SullyCNBC Jeff says its an "earnings driven" market. Riddle me this, S&P EPS in the first quarter are basically flat, the entire gain in the S&P has been valuation (more than 3 PE multiple point rise) and not earnings driven! @EconguyRosie
